title: Saudi Crown Prince Cements Authority Over Economy With Energy Ministry Pick
text:
Mohammed bin Salman ’s placement of a royal insider at the helm of Saudi Arabia’s powerful energy ministry tightens the crown prince’s ﻿ grip on one of the most important levers of the kingdom’s economy.

Successive Saudi kings had avoided naming a royal to lead the energy ministry for fear it would place too much power in one branch of the ruling family. But Sunday’s appointment of Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, an experienced oil official and son of the king, upends that arrangement, allowing his younger half brother, Prince Mohammed, to consolidate his considerable political and economic clout.

“This appointment is very important for what it signals for the balance of power in the royal family—or the nonbalance of power,” said Robin Mills, an oil expert and chief executive of Dubai-based Qamar Energy. “It’s part of MBS trying to stamp his control,” he said, using the crown prince’s initials.

Prince Abdulaziz succeeded Khalid al Falih days after the nonroyal also lost his job as chairman of Aramco, known officially as Saudi Arabian Oil Co. The head of the country’s sovereign-wealth fund and a confidante of the crown prince, Yasir al-Rumayyan, was handed that role, meaning oil-policy decisions are now split between two of his political loyalists.

The shake-up of the kingdom’s energy leadership follows Prince Mohammed taking control of other critical government organs, such as the defense ministry and national guard. Yet since his father, King Salman, ascended to the throne in 2015, Prince Mohammed had resisted putting his stamp of authority on a ministry that helps determine global oil prices.

Prince Mohammed, Saudi Arabia’s day-to-day ruler, is now trying to boost low oil prices that have been hurting growth and slowing the pace of an economic-overhaul program. That program aims to open industries—such as tourism, hospitality and entertainment—to generate jobs and to make the kingdom economy less energy dependent.

At the center of the crown prince’s plans is the coming initial public offering of Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest energy company. The former energy minister, Mr. Falih, had publicly supported a stock offering, but also worked to delay and reduce in scope, Aramco executives, advisers and Saudi officials said.

Because of his close sibling ties to Prince Mohammed—and the de facto leader’s broader consolidation of power across Saudi bureaucracy—Prince Abdulaziz isn’t expected to have much leverage to dispute his younger brother’s views, some analysts and Saudi officials said.

“I don’t see him rocking boats or challenging certain policies,” a senior Saudi official said.

Prince Abdulaziz’s first public test will come this week at a meeting of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies in the United Arab Emirates, where the Saudi-led cartel is expected to discuss production cuts that have struggled to boost oil prices. Subdued levels are punishing Saudi Arabia’s economy and threatening Prince Mohammed’s ability to invest in new non-oil industries and attract foreign investment.

Saudi officials, including Prince Abdulaziz, have unsuccessfully sought to stimulate oil prices in recent months, in part to increase the valuation of Aramco ahead of potential listing. Prince Mohammed wants to sell about 5% of the company in a process that could begin this year and he hopes will raise as much as $100 billion to invest domestically.

Prince Abdulaziz, who earned a masters of business administration from King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals in 1985, has decadeslong experience in oil markets. He started attending OPEC meetings in 1987 as an adviser at the Saudi oil ministry. “Other Saudi officials relied on an army of blue-eyed consultants. But he brought his own calculator and crunched the numbers himself,” said an OPEC official.

In 1995, Prince Abdulaziz was named deputy to the recently appointed oil minister Ali al-Naimi. For years, he was mentioned as a candidate to replace Mr. Naimi but Mr. Falih, a nonroyal, was appointed as minister instead in 2016.

“Everyone assumed that the king and the crown prince would keep the good old rule of keeping royals out of the oil sector,” a Saudi official said.

Prince Mohammed initially reinforced that perception. He sidelined his older brother, Prince Abdulaziz, demoting him in April 2017 from deputy oil minister to a less influential position as state minister for energy affairs.

The crown prince, who is 25 years younger than the oil minister, saw in the multilingual Prince Abdulaziz, who enjoys art-house cinema and French architecture, a potential rival in global economic circles, people close to Prince Abdulaziz said at the time.

Since then, Prince Abdulaziz has gradually regained influence among his family. He was given the responsibility to negotiate the reopening of joint oil fields with Kuwait and to persuade the U.S. to sell its nuclear technologies to the kingdom, people who know him said.

People who have worked with Prince Abdulaziz say he is very focused on minute details, such as flower arrangements or finger food in meetings. He has a reputation inside OPEC for bargaining hard at the table, notably with Saudi Arabia’s chief rival Iran, delegates he has befriended over more than a decade.

Through decades of high-stakes energy meetings, he has maintained an impish sense of humor. In the middle of one tense OPEC committee, when delegates couldn’t decide on the date of their next gathering, the prince stunned those in the room by singing the theme from the American television sitcom “Happy Days.”

description: Mohammed bin Salman upended tradition by picking a royal insider to head the powerful ministry.
